Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Examining Formative Assessment Practices for English Language Learners in Science Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a two-year exploratory study to identify critical aspects of effective science formative assessment (FA) practices for English Language Learners (ELLs), and the contextual factors influencing such practices. Three institutions join efforts for this purpose: University of Colorado at Boulder, University of Colorado at Denver, and University of Washington. FA, in the context of the study, is viewed as a process contributing to the science learning of ELLs, as opposed to the administration of discrete sets of instruments to collect data from students. The study targets Spanish-speaking, elementary and middle school students. Findings from this study contribute to advance knowledge and understanding of FA as an inherent component of the science learning process in linguistically diverse classrooms, and to define a research agenda aimed at enhancing science teachers' ability to enact equitable and effective assessment practices for this student subpopulation.


Three research questions guide the work: (1) What FA practices are occurring in science classrooms that serve predominantly mainstream students and in those serving predominantly ELLs?; (2) How are teachers' FA practices for mainstream students different from or similar to those used with ELLs?; and (3) How do contextual factors and teachers' cultural and linguistic competencies influence FA practices? To address these questions, two conceptual frameworks are used--one for characterizing FA events; the other for examining FA events as a communication process. The study employs a mixed-methods research approach with emphasis on case studies. The sample size consists of three school districts in Colorado and Washington, 16 classrooms (8 elementary, 8 middle school), 16 teachers, and 96 ELLs. Classrooms are selected to represent a particular combination of four factors: (a) teacher ethnicity, (b) teacher formal academic preparation in teaching ELLs, (c) type of linguistic student background, and (d) grade level. Students are selected through a stratified random sample, identified by achievement level (i.e., low, medium, high), and linguistic background (i.e., mainstream, ELL). Data collection strategies to document the implementation of FA at the beginning, during, and at the end of a science unit include: (a) classroom observation protocols, (b) classroom video-recording, (c) video/artifact simulated recall, (d) assessment artifacts, (e) student interviews, (f) teacher questionnaires, (g) teacher interviews, (h) school principal interviews, and (i) school observations. Reliability and validity of most of the data-gathering instruments is determined through pilot studies. Data interpretation strategies include: (a) coding based on the two conceptual frameworks, (b) scoring rubrics to identify levels of effectiveness, and (c) narratives and profiles to describe FA patterns. Publications and the development of a website constitute the main dissemination strategies. A technical advisory board is responsible for formative and summative evaluation. Key evaluation questions are: (1) To what extent does the project enhance research on ELL FA practices through case studies?, and (2) How effectively do the project dissemination activities facilitate understanding of FA practices?

Major project outcomes include: (1) a description of the patterns of formal and informal FA practices for ELLs; (2) a comparison of the FA practices observed in classrooms that vary on the dimensions of teacher characteristics and linguistic diversity; and (3) an empirically and theoretically informed set of findings and strategies for supporting teachers to enact and enhance FA practices sensitive to cultural and linguistic diversity. Three main products are developed: (1) a monograph describing the FA practices observed across the different classrooms with concrete examples; (2) a description of possible professional development strategies to improve in-service FA practices for linguistically diverse students; and (3) a research-informed approach for analyzing FA practices. Besides filling the existing research gap on FA with ELLs, outcomes and products serve as a foundation for a future research agenda and a comprehensive project aimed at ensuring equitable science learning for all students, including ELLs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative exploratory research project addressed the fact that while formative assessment (FA) depends heavily on social interaction mediated by language, research on FA has paid sparse attention to cultural and linguistic diversity. We investigated teachers’ FA practices in science classrooms with English language learners (ELLs)—students who are acquiring English as a second language.

 

We developed a coding system that captured: how teachers’ actions addressed language and language-related issues in their FA and instructional activities; and whether those actions focused only on ELLs or were directed to the whole class, only to non-ELL students, or to both ELL and non-ELL students. For each of these four student group configurations, instructional practices were coded according to 33 dichotomous variables (present—absent) at two levels of analysis—lesson and instructional episode.

 

We video recorded all the daily lessons taught by 10 middle-school teachers who taught a total of 13 instructional units. Our sample of teachers included: 1) White, monolingual teachers who were native English users and taught in English-only programs in classrooms in which the majority of the students were white students, native English users; and 2) Latino teachers who were native users of Spanish and taught in bilingual programs in classroom in which the majority of the students were Latino students who were also native Spanish users.

 

We randomly selected six lessons at the beginning, middle, and end of each instructional unit and partitioned every lesson into distinguishable instructional episodes. In total, we coded 78 lessons and 359 instructional episodes within those lessons. Two coders coded these lessons and instructional episodes in two stages: independent and negotiated (in which coders compared their independent coding and discussed and resolved any differences).

 

Data analyses focused on the absolute and relative frequencies of the instructional and FA practices observed at both the lesson and the instructional episode level across student group configurations. A series of analysis of variance and generalizability studies allowed examination of main score differences between teachers, inter-rater reliability, and the extent to which score variation was due to the main and interaction effect of teacher, student group configuration, coder, and coding stage.

 

We found that raters were consistent in their scoring; on average, the main and interaction effect of coder accounted for about 1% of the total score variation observed across the 33 variables in the independent coding stage. Also, we observed a minimum effect in score variation due to coding stage; coders tended to be consistent across the independent and negotiated coding.

 

Our results revealed a pattern according to which most of the FA and instructional practices were directed to the whole class and rarely small group configurations. The relative frequencies of teachers’ instructional practices tended to be comparably low for the Only ELL, Mainstream, and Mixed (ELL and non-ELL) configurations, with the Mixed configuration as the lowest. The same pattern was observed when the data were disaggregated according to the ethnicity of the teachers.

 

The main finding of this project concerns the ways in which science instructional and FA practices fail to properly serve ELL students. As indicated by the relative frequencies of instructional and FA practices observed, ELL group student configurations receive as much attention from the teachers as non-ELL and mixed configurations do. However, the teacher attention received by these three small group configuration was extremely low—teachers paid most of their attention to and perform most of their instructional and FA activities with the whole class. In the science classroom, ELL students appear to be in disadvantage to their non-ELL counterparts, not because teachers behave differentially across small group configurations but because most of their activities are performed with the whole class and whole class activities are unlikely to be sensitive to specific student’s needs.

We also observed that, although many interactions teachers have with their students in their science classes address academic language, most of these interactions address basic levels of language use. For example, vocabulary is more frequently addressed than scientific discourse. Furthermore, while Latino, native Spanish speaking teachers tend to be more sensitive than their White, monolingual English speaking counterparts to the aspects in which ELL students need support concerning language, both types of teachers support their ELL students with comparable, (albeit limited) effectiveness.

 

Our findings have important professional development implications. Key to meeting the unique set of each student’s needs, differentiated instruction is predicated on the premise that teachers work frequently with students individually or in small groups. Our findings show that differentiated instruction is unlikely to occur under conditions in which the vast majority of instructional and FA activities performed by teachers (regardless of their ethnicity and formal training) focus on the entire whole class. Classroom work with small student groups, especially those involving ELL students, is critical to creating equitable science instruction.
